title.narrative: BRACED X: Changing farming practices in Burkina Faso, an extension of BRACED

description.narrative: Impact: BRES-X seeks to contribute to an increase of disposable household income by 15% and to increase the proportion of food secure households by 15% since the start of BRACED-1 in January 2015. Outcome: BRES-X will continue strengthening farmers’ resilience to enhance food security and income. Between the end of BRACED and the end of BRACED-X the number of beneficiaries with strengthened resilience will be consolidated at 70% of the beneficiary population, but the proportion of beneficiaries with a high degree of resilience will increase from 40% (BRACED Y2 result) to 60%.

The BRES-X project seeks to support 620,000 people (285,200 men; 334,800 women), but the activities of the project will be concentrated in 20 to 25 communes (out of 32 supported under BRACED-1). In more detail the project will strengthen the resilience of 440,000 individuals (202,400 men; 237,600 women). The project targets women specifically with certain work packages and High Intensity activities, works with women as lead farmers and raises awareness on gender and decision making in a context of a changing climate. These combined efforts have proven to yield positive effects during BRACED-1, especially if women can participate in multiple activities that diversify their sources of income.

The project will build the economic, ecological and organisational resilience of 620,000 rural people in Burkina Faso and strengthen their ability to cope with the effects of increased rainfall variability and higher temperatures. This will be achieved by diversifying agricultural production and increasing incomes (through improved, sustainable access to drought-tolerant seeds, soil fertility improvement and enterprise development), together with strengthened government extension services to reduce crop losses and early-warning weather systems. The project will scale proven resilience-building approaches, embed climate adaptation approaches in local, regional and national plans, and generate and disseminate best practice guidance on climate adaptation approaches.
